subject: Re: [junit] Testing all
msgSnippet: ... In the sample AllTests.java, the intent of the line suite.addTest(junit.tests.AllTests.suite()); is to add the AllTests class in a *different* package.
messageBody:
--- Ghielli Patrick <Patrick.Ghielli@...> wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I have written the following class to execute all my tests (only a
> few since
> we're just starting). I copied most of it from some example. It does
> not
> really work, however. If I include the constructor I get the error
> that
> there are no tests in AllTest. When I exclude the constructor I get
> the
> error that the class has no public constructor. Is there anyone that
> can
> shed a light on this problem.
>
> thanx and greetz,
> Patrick.
>
>
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class AllTests {
>
> public AllTests(String testname){
> //super(testname);
> }
>
> public static void main(String args[]){
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> }
>
> public static Test suite(){
> TestSuite t_suite= new TestSuite("All User tests");
> t_suite.addTest( UserServletTests.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( new TestSuite(UserServletTests.class));
> t_suite.addTest( UserTests.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( TestUserLogon.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( RegisterTest.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( junit.tests.AllTests.suite());
> return t_suite;
> }
> }
>

In the sample AllTests.java, the intent of the line

suite.addTest(junit.tests.AllTests.suite());

is to add the AllTests class in a *different* package. Notice that the
sample is in the junit.samples packages, rather than the junit.tests
package.

In your case, you'll either want to remove this line or redefine it to
add an AllTests class from another package.

Mike
